title: Fiatless
author: Fiatless
content: The speeches of Donald Trump, Robert F Kennedy, US Senators Bill Hagerty, Cynthia Lummis, and Tim Scott at this year's Bitcoin Conference in Nashville, Tennessee, received the spotlight in the Bitcoin community. Donald Trump and Robert F Kennedy spoke so well about Bitcoin thereby receiving applause and cheers from attendees. I was also thrilled by their comments because it will affect the Bitcoin space positively.Trump said Bitcoin is a wonder to the world and will soon overtake gold. He promised to make the US the crypto capital of the world. Kennedy also promised to apply the same strategy of Nayib Bukele of El Salvador by making the US buy 500 BTC daily until the country's reserve gets to 4 million BTC. Such a wonderful promise.There is no way we can verify the true intentions of these sweet talkers.But the greatest and the most truthful message came from Edward Snowden  and it reads:Quote“Cast a vote, but don’t join a cult". “They are not our tribe. They are not your personality. They have their own interests, their own values, their own things they’re chasing. Try to get what you need from them, but don’t give yourself to them, even if you have to vote for them.”

That's their way of life.  Ex-President Trump is really making some big promises for the bitcoin community, which might give him issues if he even has the intention of getting them done. Let's not forget that he is not the only decision-maker who will say a word and it will stand as he pronounced it; everything follows due process, and if he wants to implement it without the support and vote of the house, I don't think it will go anywhere.

comments.author: DooMAD
comments.body: Politicians are inherently duplicitous.  They say all the things you want to hear because they need your vote.  But once they have power, they do the things their political donors tell them to do, because they need the money.  Once they have your vote, you don't actually matter.

comments.body: He is also saying some crazy and in some cases scary stuff...QuoteTrump announced his intent to make the United States the “crypto capital of the world” if he wins November’s presidential election.That smells like centralization.How is he going to do that? Attack countries like Kazakhstan to take their hashrate share? Crack down on any exchanges that are not in USA? ...Quotepromised to use fossil fuels to create “so much electricity that you’ll be saying, ‘Please, president sir, we have too much electricity.‘”Yeah, screw the environment But seriously, US runs (IIRC) a 8-9 million bpd fossil fuel deficit that they need to import and with the crazy things he has in mind (specially with his crazier VP Vance) fossil fuel prices could shoot up a lot more due to more conflicts he'd start. So US may both run a higher deficit and face higher prices which would be a good thing for Bitcoin because it spreads the hashrate to other countries more (means more decentralization).QuoteTrump mentioned that he believes he would be a strong candidate for the cryptocurrency and Bitcoin communities. comments.author: Dr.Bitcoin_Strange
comments.body: It's a wise saying. Even if one must vote for them, it's better to realize that all of that sweet talk might not be fulfilled by those politicians. That's my own opinion. There are lots of Bitcoiners in US, and they all want a fair and favorable Bitcoin rule that makes them comfortable in their Bitcoin investment, by knowing what the people want, the politicians can use it to sweet talk the people into believing in them, while at last, those promises will not be fulfilled.

comments.author: legiteum
comments.body: People should be terrified by Trump's comments. Trump replacing Bitcoin with a currency he wholly owns--something he could do at a push of a button as US president--would make him an instant trillionaire, and that is all Trump has ever cared about in his whole life.To stop the two million abortions occurring in the USA every year today, Trump needs to create the largest law enforcement apparatus in history, like they did at the time of the Prohibition--but much bigger this time.This is a perfect pretext for Trump to invoke the US to takeover the Bitcoin network by force and make it part of the US government, or to replace Bitcoin by outlawing Bitcoin in the US and offering his own currency as a replacement that (they would say) couldn't be used to pay for illegal abortions.There is an extremely short-sighted euphoria going on in some of the crypto community about Trump's pandering. Trump is a convicted criminal, and his election will tell him that Americans don't care about blatant criminality in the presidency--which will give him options no US president has ever had. Trump doesn't care about you, doesn't care about your Bitcoin, and is willing to break the law to get what he wants. Inviting Trump into the Bitcoin community is akin to inviting the Mafia into your business.Politicians should not be your tribe, and they should not be your... business model.

comments.author: FatFork
comments.body: Politicians tend to make a bunch of promises that sound really good when they're trying to get elected.  But you can't take all that talk at face value - they'll say just about anything to get votes and  once the elections over, suddenly those big promises aren't such a priority anymore.  So I wouldn't put too much stock in candidates claiming to be pro-crypto or whatever.  Even if some of them actually believe in it now, there's no guarantee theyll still care once they're in office.  Actions speak louder than words when it comes to politics.  If some legislators start actually putting forward and voting for bills that help the crypto space, then maybe they're serious.  But a bunch of vague campaign promises dont really mean much on their own.

comments.body: Politicians are the same they have always been. If they’re pushing Bitcoin it is because they want to raise funds from the Bitcoin community or they have a stake in it and want to use their government position to get rich. Nothing has changed. They’re doing what they do. They don’t care about the US government owning Bitcoin. They care about abusing their positions to enrich themselves. It isn’t brain surgery.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: I have always believed and said exactly this and I still believe this. Politicians don't joke with what they say. What they say can make or break them..it would be very shallow of people to vote for a politician based on what they say, I believe politicians should be voted based on their track record and their history. Ask questions like "How did they perform in their past positions". They're trained in the act of public speaking.I don't understand why the Bitcoin community will be so moved and impressed by what these guys said at a "Bitcoin conference". Do you expect them to go to a conference where they have potential voters and those potential voters as Bitcoiners and say, "Bitcoin is shit; nobody should own them"? Or say, "If I become president, I will make owning bitcoin illegal"? Of course not. They'll say positive things, things that will make you vote for them.I agree that people's views on things change, but a man like Trump becoming pro-bitcoin all of a sudden after being against Bitcoin in 2019 leaves a lot of questions. Bitcoin is going to survive with or without these people. In fact, it's doing pretty well without them. The is not a government institution or a big corporation that needs government contracts, government funding, or more shareholders to survive. So voters, please don't vote or support a person simply because he said he'll do this or that when elected; vote because you're convinced, based on your answered questions, that he/she is the best candidate.
